Her murderer was convicted. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref>{{cite web |last=Floyd |first=Jami |url=http://insession.blogs.cnn.com/2008/07/10/remembering-michelle |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514050614/http://insession.blogs.cnn.com/2008/07/10/remembering-michelle/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 14, 2011 |title=Remembering Michelle |publisher=CNN.com |date=July 10, 2008 |accessdate=January 8, 2012 }}</ref> |- | {{date|2007-02-09|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Grant, Tara" |[[Tara Grant]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 35-year-old woman murdered by her husband. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="HunterPreddy2009">{{cite book|author1=George Hunter|author2=Melissa Ann Preddy|title=Limb from Limb|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iRtPpziwhowC&pg=PA76|date=October 2009|publisher=Pinnacle Books|isbn=978-0-7860-2292-2|page=76}}</ref> |- | {{date|2007-05-03|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="McCann, Madeline" |[[Madeleine McCann]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 3-year-old girl who disappeared from her parents' hotel room during a family holiday in Portugal. Described by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' as "the most heavily reported missing-person case in modern history". | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="MMTI">{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/our-shameful-hierarchy--some-deaths-matter-more-than-others-8581715.html |title=Our shameful hierarchy – some deaths matter more than others |work=[[The Independent]] |date=April 21, 2013 |last=Jones |first=Ozen |accessdate=March 27, 2014}}</ref><ref name="MMIBT">{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/what-missing-white-woman-syndrome-1441153 |title=What is 'Missing White Woman Syndrome'? Racism in Media Coverage |work=[[International Business Times]] |date=March 20, 2014 |last=Laccino |first=Ludovica |accessdate=March 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name="MMDT">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1902515/Master-of-media-circus-for-Madeleine-McCann.html |title=Master of media circus for Madeleine McCann |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=April 24, 2008 |accessdate=March 27, 2014}}</ref> |- | {{date|2008-06-16|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Anthony, Caylee" |[[Caylee Anthony]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 2-year-old girl reported missing by her grandmother after 31 days. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Bloom /> |- | {{date|2009-02-09|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Cummings, Haleigh" |Haleigh Cummings | style="font-size:100%;" |A 5-year-old girl kidnapped from her father's trailer in [[Satsuma, Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/c/cummings_haleigh.html|title=The Charley Project: Haleigh Ann-Marie Cummings|first=Meaghan Elizabeth|last=Good|website=Charleyproject.org|accessdate=October 9, 2017}}</ref> | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Bloom>Bloom, L. (2011) ''Think Straight: Talk for Women to stay smart in a dumbed-down world.'' ReadHowYouWant.com, 504 pages</ref> |- | {{date|2009-10-05|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Symes, Aisling" |Aisling Symes | style="font-size:100%;" |A 2-year-old girl who disappeared from her home in Auckland, New Zealand. She was feared abducted but her body was found in a drain near her home a week later, and it was determined that she was the victim of accidental drowning after wandering off from her mother's side while she was carrying out household chores. Tim Hulme, writing for ''[[The Sunday Star-Times]]'', surmised that age was a much greater factor than race or class in the extensive media coverage the case garnered. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="auto3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/2975448/The-toddler-who-united-a-country|title=The toddler who united a country|last=Hume|first=Tim|date=October 18, 2009|work=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|accessdate=May 15, 2017}}</ref> |- | {{date|2011-04-13|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Bobo, Holly" |[[Holly Bobo]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 20-year-old nursing student who disappeared from her home in Darden, Tennessee. Her remains were found in September 2014. Two men have been charged with her murder and kidnapping. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="MMCR">{{cite web |last=Barton |first=Robin L. |title=The "Missing White Woman Syndrome" |publisher=The Crime Report |date=August 22, 2011 |url=http://www.thecrimereport.org/viewpoints/robin-barton/2011-08-the-missing-white-woman-syndrome |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160902163316/https://thecrimereport.org/2011/08/22/2011-08-the-missing-white-woman-syndrome/ |archivedate=September 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |subscription=yes}}</ref> |- | {{date|2011-06-03|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Spierer, Lauren" |[[Lauren Spierer]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 20-year-old Indiana University student who disappeared after a night of drinking. She remains missing. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="spierer grubb">{{cite news|last=Majchrowicz|first=Michael|title=Beyond the posters: How demographics factored in Spierer, Grubb cases|url=https://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=84052|newspaper=Indiana Daily Student|date=November 9, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304010835/https://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=84052|archivedate=March 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |- | {{date|2013-08-03|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Anderson, Hannah" |[[Kidnapping of Hannah Anderson|Hannah Anderson]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 16-year-old California high school student who was kidnapped by a family friend after cheerleading practice. She was found in Idaho after a weeklong national search. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Sommers /> |- | {{date|2014-09-13|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Graham, Hannah" |[[Murder of Hannah Graham|Hannah Graham]] | style="font-size:100%;" |An 18-year-old University of Virginia student who was kidnapped and murdered by an acquaintance. Her remains were found approximately five weeks after her disappearance. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref>{{cite news |url=http://splinternews.com/i-am-a-girl-now-sage-smith-wrote-then-she-went-missin-1797178002 |title='I Am a Girl Now,' Sage Smith Wrote. Then She Went Missing. |author=Eisenberg, Emma |editor=Aronowitz, Nona Willis |date=24 July 2017 |publisher=Splinter News |accessdate=26 July 2017}}</ref> |- | {{date|2016-08-22|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Quer, Diana" |Diana Quer | style="font-size:100%;" |An 18-year-old girl from a wealthy [[Madrid]] family who disappeared while vacationing in [[A Pobra do Caramiñal]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]]. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name = "García">{{cite news |last=García |first=José Manuel |date=September 9, 2016 |title=Diana Quer: Se busca mujer blanca, joven y de familia rica |trans-title=Diana Quer: Missing white woman, young and from a wealthy family|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/sucesos/20160909/41175733575/se-busca-mujer-blanca-joven-familia-rica.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |location=Barcelona, Spain |access-date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> |- | {{date|2018-07-16|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Tibbets, Mollie" |[[Disappearance of Mollie Tibbetts|Mollie Tibbetts]] | style="font-size:100%;" | 20-year-old who disappeared while jogging near her home in [[Brooklyn, Iowa]]. Her body was discovered over a month later on August 21. | style="text-align:center;" | <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2018/08/21/mollie-tibbetts-has-been-found-dead-a-month-after-she-vanished-authorities-say/?noredirect=on |title=Mollie Tibbetts has been found dead a month after she vanished, authorities say |publisher=The Washington Post |date=August 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fox23.com/news/national-news/mollie-tibbetts-gets-far-more-coverage-than-other-missing-iowans-is-media-bias-to-blame/803552523 |title=Mollie Tibbetts gets far more coverage than other missing persons. Is media bias to blame? |publisher=USA Today |date=August 1, 2018}}</ref> |}
===Contemporary cases claimed not to have received comparable attention=== <!-- THIS IS NOT A LIST OF MISSING PERSONS. ONLY ADD CASES THAT HAVE BEEN LINKED TO MWWS IN RELIABLE SOURCES --> The following missing person cases have been expressly compared to contemporary missing person cases labeled as examples of "Missing White Woman Syndrome", in order to hightlight differences in coverage between them. The date of death or disappearance is given in parentheses.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col" class="date" style="width: 10em"| Date ! scope="col" class="text" style="width: 12em"| Name ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Description ! scope="col" class="text" style="width: 12em"| Case contrasted with ! scope="col" class="unsortable" style="width: 5em" | Source(s) |- | Unknown ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Nath, Srey" |Srey Nath | style="font-size:100%;" | A 15-year-old [[Cambodia]]n student lured to [[Thailand]] with a job offer and enslaved in a [[Malaysia]]n brothel. After escaping with three other girls and reporting to police, she was jailed for a year for [[illegal immigration]] and subsequently deported to Thailand, where she was sold to another brothel. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Dugard, Jaycee" |[[Jaycee Dugard]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Bloom /> |- | 1993 - ongoing ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Ciudad Juárez" |[[Female homicides in Ciudad Juárez]] | style="font-size:100%;" | Over 800 violent deaths of women and girls in the Mexican border city of [[Ciudad Juárez]]. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Holloway, Natalee" |[[Natalee Holloway]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Gaspar>Gaspar de Alba, A. (2014) ''[Un]framing the "Bad Woman": Sor Juana, Malinche, Coyolxauhqui, and other rebels with a cause.'' University of Texas Press, 400 pages</ref> |- | rowspan="4"|{{date|2000-11-27|mdy}} ! rowspan="4" style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Taylor, Damilola" |[[Damilola Taylor]] | rowspan="4"|A 10-year-old [[Nigeria]]n boy who was stabbed by a random attacker in [[London]] and died from [[blood loss]] while being driven to a hospital. The coverage centered on the general safety of the area and largely ignored the victim. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Payne, Sarah" |[[Murder of Sarah Payne|Sarah Payne]] | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="4"| <ref name=Jewkes /> |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Dowler, Milly" |[[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]] |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Chapman, Jessica" |[[Soham Murders|Jessica Chapman]] |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Wells, Holly" |[[Soham Murders|Holly Wells]] |- | rowspan="2"|{{date|2001-04-01|mdy}} ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Williams, Hannah" |[[Murder of Hannah Williams|Hannah Williams]] | rowspan="2" style="font-size:100%;" |A 14-year-old London working-class girl with a history of running away from home, who disappeared during a shopping trip. Her body was discovered a year later during the search for a middle-class missing girl, Danielle Jones, and most of the (scarce) coverage Williams received was early speculation about the possibility of her body being Jones's. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Jones, Danielle" |[[Murder of Danielle Jones|Danielle Jones]] | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/mar/28/gender.uk|title=Why is this the first we've heard of Hannah Williams?|first=Raekha|last=Prasad|date=March 28, 2002|accessdate=October 9, 2017|website=Theguardian.com}}</ref> |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Dowler, Milly" |[[Murder of Milly Dowler|Milly Dowler]] |- | rowspan="2"|{{date|2002-07-24|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Hernandez, Evelyn" |Evelyn Hernandez | rowspan="2"|A 24-year-old, almost nine months pregnant [[El Salvador|Salvadoran]] immigrant and her American 6-year-old son, who went missing in [[San Francisco]]. Evelyn's torso was found in the [[San Francisco Bay]] three months later, while Alex remains missing. ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Peterson, Laci" |[[Laci Peterson]] | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2"| <ref>{{cite news |title= The "other" Laci Peterson: Who killed Evelyn Hernandez?|url=http://people.com/archive/the-other-laci-peterson-who-killed-evelyn-hernandez-vol-60-no-1/ |date=July 7, 2003 | newspaper=People |last=Hewitt |first=Bill |accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref> |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Hernandez, Alex" |Alex Hernandez |- | rowspan="2"|{{date|2003-03-23|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Piestewa, Lori" |[[Lori Piestewa]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 23-year-old [[United States Army]] soldier, of [[Hopi]] descent and a single mother, killed at the Battle of Nasiriyah. ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value ="Lynch, Jessica" |[[Jessica Lynch]] | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="Robinson" /><ref name="auto1"/><ref name="auto2"/> |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Johnson, Shoshana" |[[Shoshana Johnson]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 30-year-old [[United States Army]] [[Specialist (rank)|specialist]], of [[Afro-Panamanian]] descent and a single mother, injured and taken prisoner at the Battle of Nasiriyah. |- | {{date|2005-02-25|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Cooke, Donna" |Donna Cooke | style="font-size:100%;" | A 23-year-old prostitute found strangled in [[Lake Thonotosassa]] during the search for Jessica Lunsford. Coverage of the then unidentified woman was reduced to the Sheriff reassuring viewers that "it is not our girl" (meaning Lunsford), which was denounced as "dehumanizing" by critics. Cooke's murder remains unsolved. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Anthony, Caylee" |[[Jessica Lunsford]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref>Stillman, S. (2007). ‘The missing white girl syndrome’: disappeared women and media activism. Gender & Development, 15(3), 491-502.</ref> |- | {{date|2005-07-18|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Figueroa, LaToyia" |[[LaToyia Figueroa]] | style="font-size:100%;" |A 24-year-old, five months pregnant [[Afrolatino|Afrolatina]] waitress (and already a single mother) who disappeared in [[Philadelphia]] after leaving a [[prenatal care]] session. Her remains were discovered in [[Chester, Pennsylvania]] one month later. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Holloway, Natalee" |[[Natalee Holloway]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/us/missing-womans-case-spurs-discussion-of-news-coverage.html|title=Missing Woman's Case Spurs Discussion of News Coverage|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=9 October 2017}}</ref> |- | {{date|2007-03-10|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Vargas, Yéremi" |Yéremi Vargas | style="font-size:100%;" |A poor 7-year-old boy who disappeared while playing in a vacant lot of [[Vecindario]], [[Gran Canaria]]. The disappearance had little repercusion for the first five years. Antonio Ojeda, a [[pedophile]] incarcerated for abusing another child, was named the main suspect in 2016. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="McCann, Madeleine" |[[Madeleine McCann]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Rada /> |- | rowspan="2"|{{date|2009-01-08|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Garcia-Calles, Oscar" |Oscar Garcia-Calles | rowspan="2"|Two Salvadoran brothers aged 16 and 14 who disappeared while traveling to [[Green Brook, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.findthemissing.org/en/cases/6102/65|title=NamUs - National Missing Persons Data System - Samuel Garcia-Calles - MP # 6102|website=Findthemissing.org|accessdate=October 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://findthemissing.org/en/cases/6103/141|title=NamUs - National Missing Persons Data System - Oscar Garcia-Calles - MP # 6103|website=findthemissing.org|accessdate=October 9, 2017}}</ref> Possibly abducted by an unrelated adult male. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Van Dam, Danielle" |[[Danielle Van Dam]] | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2"| <ref name=Bloom /> |- ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Garcia-Calles, Samuel" |Samuel Garcia-Calles ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Lunsford, Jessica" |[[Jessica Lunsford]] |- | {{date|2009-04-29|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Solel, Shalomiel" |Shalomiel Solel | style="font-size:100%;" | A 3-year-old African-American boy abducted by his non-custodial parents from [[Carson, California]]. Found undernourished and living on the streets with his parents in [[New Orleans]], on March 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/resolved/resolved71.html|title=The Charley Project: Resolved Cases|first=Meaghan Elizabeth|last=Good|website=Charleyproject.org|accessdate=October 9, 2017}}</ref> ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Anthony, Caylee" |[[Caylee Anthony]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Bloom /> |- | {{date|2009-10-01|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Rayadurgam, Srikanth" |Srikanth Rayadurgam | style="font-size:100%;" |A 23-year-old [[India]]n student disappeared in [[Auckland, New Zealand]]. Rayadurgam's family denounced that a [[Wellington, New Zealand|Wellington]] team originally assigned to investigate his disappearance was redirected in short notice to [[Henderson, New Zealand|Henderson]] in order to assist on the search of 2-year-old Aisling Symes. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Symes, Aisling" |Aisling Symes | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="auto3"/> |- | {{date|2010-05-30|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Flores, Stephany" |[[Stephany Flores]] | style="font-size:100%;" | A 21-year-old Peruvian business student murdered in a hotel room by [[Joran van der Sloot]], the main suspect of the Natalee Holloway case. ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Holloway, Natalee" |[[Natalee Holloway]] | style="text-align:center;" | <ref name=Gaspar /> |- | {{date|2016-07-05|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Chavero, Manuela" |Manuela Chavero | style="font-size:100%;" |A 42-year-old woman who disappeared in the early morning from her home in [[Monesterio]], [[Extremadura]]; she left the TV on, her cell phone in the kitchen, and her pants on the bed. ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Quer, Diana" |Diana Quer | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | <ref name="García"/><ref name = "Rada">{{cite news |last=Rada |first=Juan |date=September 11, 2016 |title=Desaparecida 'rica', desaparecida 'pobre': Por qué se habla de Diana Quer y no de Manuela Chavero|trans-title='Rich' missing, 'poor' missing: Why [people] talk of Diana Quer and not Manuela Chavero|url=https://www.elespanol.com/reportajes/grandes-historias/20160910/154484842_0.html|language=Spanish |work=El Español |location=Madrid, Spain |access-date=September 18, 2017}}</ref> |- | {{date|2016-08-25|mdy}} ! style="text-align:left;" data-sort-value="Durán, Iván" |Iván Durán | style="font-size:100%;" |A 30-year-old man from [[Baiona, Pontevedra|Baiona]], Galicia, disappeared 3 days after Diana Quer. |}

revision.comment: /* See also */ [[Museum of the Moon]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Moon_Art_Scale_Fingers.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 300px | title = Moon Museum | alt = | type = [[ceramic]] [[Wafer (electronics)|wafer]] | artist = [[John Chamberlain (sculptor)|John Chamberlain]], [[Forrest Myers]], [[:de:David_Novros|David Novros]], [[Claes Oldenburg]], [[Robert Rauschenberg]] and [[Andy Warhol]] | year = {{Start date|1969}} | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = 0.75 | width_imperial = 0.5 | imperial_unit = in | metric_unit = cm | city = [[Mare Cognitum]] | museum = [[Apollo 12]] [[Apollo Lunar Module|Lunar Module ''Intrepid'']] | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''''Moon Museum''''' is a small [[ceramic]] [[Wafer (electronics)|wafer]] three-quarters of an inch by half an inch in size,<ref name="History"> [https://www.pbs.org/opb/historydetectives/diyinv/2010/06/diy-moon-museum.html Who is John F.?], ''[[History Detectives]]'', [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]], Season 8, Episode 1, June 7, 2010. Accessed July 14, 2010</ref> containing artworks by six prominent artists from the late 1960s. The artists with works in the "museum" are [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[:de:David_Novros|David Novros]], [[John Chamberlain (sculptor)|John Chamberlain]], [[Claes Oldenburg]], [[Forrest Myers]] and [[Andy Warhol]].<ref name="History" />
This wafer was supposedly covertly attached to a leg of the [[Apollo Lunar Module|Lunar Module ''Intrepid'']], and subsequently left on the Moon during [[Apollo 12]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cory |first1=Doctorow |title=Secret museum on the moon's surface / Boing Boing |url=https://boingboing.net/2008/02/29/secret-museum-on-the.html |website=boingboing.net |accessdate=21 June 2018 |date=29 February 2008}}</ref> ''Moon Museum'' is considered the first Space Art object.<ref> [http://www.tampamuseum.org/exhibitions/current The Moon Museum: First Space Art Object Lands at Tampa Museum of Art] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714020938/http://www.tampamuseum.org/exhibitions/current |date=2011-07-14 }}. [[Tampa Museum of Art]] June 18 - August 1, 2010. Accessed July 15, 2010.</ref> While it is impossible to tell if ''Moon Museum'' is actually on the Moon without sending another mission to look, technicians have admitted to placing personal effects onto the Apollo landers, hidden in the layers of gold blankets that wrapped parts of the spacecraft which remained on the Moon after the astronauts departed.<ref name="History" />
==History== The concept for ''Moon Museum'' was brainstormed by Forrest "Frosty" Myers. He stated that "My idea was to get six great artists together and make a tiny little museum that would be on the moon."<ref name="History" /> Myers attempted several times to get his project sanctioned by [[NASA]]. He claims the agency gave him the runaround and, Myers states, "They never said no, I just could not get them to say anything."<ref name="History" /> Instead of going through the official channels, he was forced to take the back route and try to smuggle it on board. [[File:Moon museum nyt.jpg|thumb|left|Image of the Moon Museum from the original ''New York Times'' article. The thumb obscures Warhol's drawing.]]
Myers contacted [[Experiments in Art and Technology]] (E.A.T.), a non-profit group that was linking artists with engineers to create new works. Through E.A.T., Myers was introduced to some scientists from [[Bell Laboratories]], specifically [[Fred Waldhauer]]. Using techniques normally used to produce telephone circuits, the scientists etched the drawings Myers had gathered onto small ceramic wafers. Either 16 or 20 of these wafers were created,<ref name="History" /> with one going on the lunar lander and the rest, copies of the original, handed out to the artists and others involved in the project.<ref name="AOL">{{cite web |url=http://www.aolnews.com/weird-news/article/tiny-art-museum-hidden-aboard-apollo-12-for-its-moon-landing/19516542 |title=Warhol in Space: Apollo 12 Secretly Carried Art to the Moon |last1=Moye |first1=David |last2= |first2= |date=17 June 2010 |website=Aol News |publisher= |access-date=14 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618232925/http://www.aolnews.com/weird-news/article/tiny-art-museum-hidden-aboard-apollo-12-for-its-moon-landing/19516542|archivedate=18 June 2010|quote=}}</ref>
When NASA dithered whether the wafer would be allowed onto the module, Waldhauer devised another plan. Waldhauer knew a [[Grumman Aircraft]] engineer who was working on the Apollo 12 lander module, and he proved willing to place the wafer on it.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/aboutpbs/news/20100607_historydetectivesandywarholartonmoon.html PBS' HISTORY DETECTIVES PUTS A QUESTION TO THE NATION: IS ANDY WARHOL’S ART ON THE MOON?]. PBS. June 7, 2010. Accessed July 14, 2010</ref> Myers asked Waldhauer how he would know if the art actually made it onto the lander, and was told that the person who worked for Grumman would send him a [[telegram]] when the wafer was in place. At 3:35 p.m. on November 12, 1969, less than two days before Apollo 12 took off, Myers received a telegram at his house from [[Cape Canaveral]], [[Florida]] stating "YOUR ON' A.O.K. ALL SYSTEMS GO," and signed "JOHN F."<ref name="History" />
The existence of the work was not revealed until Myers informed ''[[The New York Times]]'' which ran an article on the story two days after Apollo 12 left the Moon and two days before they splashed down in the Pacific Ocean.<ref name="greg">[http://greg.org/archive/2008/02/28/the_moon_museum.html Holy ^%$&! Man Smuggles Art To The &%#$ing Moon!] Greg.com. February 8, 2008. Accessed July 14, 2010</ref>
==Artworks== [[File:Moon Art PBS.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Supposedly one of the 15 or 19 copies of ''Moon Museum''. {| style="border: 1px solid darkgray;" align="right" |- align="center" ! !! Artwork Placement |- align="center" | [[Andy Warhol|Warhol]] || [[Robert Rauschenberg|Rauschenberg]] || [[David Novros|Novros]] |- align="center" | [[Forrest Myers|Myers]] || [[Claes Oldenburg|Oldenburg]] || [[John Chamberlain (sculptor)|Chamberlain]] |}]]
There are six artworks located on the ceramic tile, each one in black and white. Starting in the top center is a single line by [[Robert Rauschenberg]]. To its right is a black square with thin white lines intersecting, resembling a piece of circuitry, by David Novros. Below it is [[John Chamberlain (sculptor)|John Chamberlain]]'s contribution, a template pattern which also resembles circuitry. In the lower middle is a geometric variation on [[Mickey Mouse]], by [[Claes Oldenburg]], a popular motif for the artist at that time. [[Forrest Myers]] created the work in the lower left, a computer-generated drawing of a "linked symbol" called "Interconnection". Finally, the last drawing in the upper left is by [[Andy Warhol]]. He created a stylized version of his initials which, when viewed at certain angles, can appear as a [[rocket ship]] or a [[penis]].<ref name="History" /><ref name="5 July 2015">{{cite web |last1=Stinson |first1=Elizabeth |title=We Sent a Dick Pic to the Moon—And We're Doing It Again |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/05/we-sent-a-dick-pic-to-the-moon/ |website=WIRED |accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="moma">{{cite web | url =https://www.moma.org/collection/works/62272 | title =The Moon Museum | publisher =[[Museum of Modern Art]] | access-date =April 28, 2017}}</ref> "He was being the terrible bad boy," said Forrest Myers in an interview.<ref name="History" /> Warhol's work is covered by a thumb in the image often associated with ''Moon Museum'', but other images with the drawing visible can be found.<ref name= "greg" />
Both John Chamberlain and Claes Oldenburg have confirmed through representatives that they contributed drawings to ''Moon Museum''.<ref name="AOL" />
==See also== * ''[[Fallen Astronaut]]'' * ''[[Museum of the Moon]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70811F93E591A7493C0AB178AD95F4D8685F9&scp=1&sq=art+on+the+moon%3F&st=p Original ''New York Times'' article]

'''Motherhood Studies''' is a recognized field of study <ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/913869685|title=Performing motherhood : artistic, activist, and everyday enactments|last=1963-|first=Kinser, Amber E.,|date=2014|publisher=Demeter Press|isbn=9781927335925|oclc=913869685}}</ref> coined by Dr. [[Andrea O'Reilly]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Green|first=Fiona Joy|title=Motherhood Studies|date=2010|url=http://sk.sagepub.com/reference/motherhood/n441.xml|work=Encyclopedia of Motherhood|pages=832–832|publisher=SAGE Publications, Inc.|doi=10.4135/9781412979276.n441|access-date=2018-09-18}}</ref> It is related to [[maternal feminism]].
== Definition == The idea of motherhood studies was influenced by [[Adrienne Rich]]’s ''Of Woman Born: Motherhood as Experience and Institution'' in 1976. It is consists of three interconnected categories of inquiry: motherhood as institution, motherhood as experience, and motherhood as identity or subjectivity.<ref>{{Citation|last=Green|first=Fiona Joy|title=Motherhood Studies|date=2010|url=http://sk.sagepub.com/reference/motherhood/n441.xml|work=Encyclopedia of Motherhood|pages=832–832|publisher=SAGE Publications, Inc.|doi=10.4135/9781412979276.n441|access-date=2018-09-18}}</ref> Motherhood studies is often referred to as a [[Feminism|feminist practice]]. Feminist mothering critiques the sexist and patriarchal values that contemporary society upholds.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/191767744|title=Feminist mothering|last=1961-|first=O'Reilly, Andrea,|date=2008|publisher=State University of New York Press|isbn=9780791475577|oclc=191767744}}</ref> Part of feminist mothering is maternal activism.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Loveless|first=Natalie S.|date=2016-12-15|title=Contemporary Mamactivist Artists: A Forum on Maternal Activist Art for the Studies in the Maternal Special Issue on The Everyday Maternal Practice: Activist Structures in Creative Work, Summer 2016|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.16995/sim.224|journal=Studies in the Maternal|volume=8|issue=2|doi=10.16995/sim.224|issn=1759-0434}}</ref>
== History == Samira Kawash argues that "the marginalization of motherhood in feminist thought was not only a political rejection of maternalist politics construed as a conservative backlash to feminism".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kawash|first=Samira|date=2011-06|title=New Directions in Motherhood Studies|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/658637|journal=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|volume=36|issue=4|pages=969–1003|doi=10.1086/658637|issn=0097-9740}}</ref>
One of the leading portals of mother studies is ''The m/other voices foundation'', a non-profit organization in the USA. It emerged in 2014 from Deirdre M. Donoghue's research project ''(m)other voices: the maternal as an attitude, maternal thinking and the production of time and knowledge'' at [[Witte de With Center for Contemporary Art|Witte de With Centre for Contemporary Art]]. The project's purpose was to initiate discourse and the doing of maternal theory within arts and other fields of cultural production and to reflect on the maternal figure as a thinker and a producer of knowledge.
More and more organized initiatives within academic communities are starting such as the ''[https://jarm.journals.yorku.ca/index.php/jarm/index Motherhood Initiative for Research and Community Involvement]'', a feminist scholarly and activist organization on mothering-motherhood based in Toronto, Canada.
The ''Journal of the Motherhood Initiative'' re-launched in 2010 as a continuation of the ''Journal of the Association for Research on Mothering'' that started in 1999.
== Key Texts == Kinser, Amber, ed. ''Mothering in the Third Wave''. Toronto: Demeter Press, 2008.
Rich, Adrienne. ''Of Woman Born: Mother- hood as Experience and Institution'', 1976.
Ross Haller Baggesen, Lise. ''Mothernism.''
Umansky, Laurie. ''Motherhood Re- conceived'', 1996.
Hays, Sharon. ''The Cultural Contradictions of Motherhood'', 1996.
== See Also == [[Museum of Motherhood]]
[[Mierle Laderman Ukeles|Manifesto for Maintenance Art, 1969]]
[[Mary Kelly (artist)|Mary Kelly]]
[[Maternal feminism|Maternal Feminism]]

revision.text:
The [[National Motor Freight Traffic Association]] publishes the '''National Motor Freight Classification®''' (NMFC®), a standard that provides a comparison of commodities moving in commerce. The NMFC® is developed and maintained by the [[Commodity Classification Standards Board]] (CCSB).
The NMFC® is a voluntary standard that provides a comparison of commodities moving in interstate, intrastate and foreign commerce. It is similar in concept to the groupings or grading systems that serve many other industries. Commodities are grouped into one of 18 classes—from a low of class 50 to a high of class 500—based on an evaluation of four transportation characteristics: density, stowability, handling and liability. Together, these characteristics establish a commodity’s “transportability.”<ref name="nmfta">{{cite web|title="The National Motor Freight Classification"|url=http://www.nmfta.org/pages/nmfc|publisher=NMFTA}}</ref>
The NMFC® also specifies minimum packaging requirements to ensure that goods are adequately protected in the motor carrier environment and can be handled and stowed in a manner that is reasonably safe and practicable. It contains various rules that govern and otherwise relate to the classification and/or packaging of commodities as well as procedures for the filing and disposition of claims, and procedures governing interline settlements. It also contains the [[Bill of lading|Uniform Straight Bill of Lading]], including its terms and conditions.<ref name="nmfta"></ref>
==See also== *[[Freight]] *[[Less than truckload shipping]] *[[Commodity Classification Standards Board]] *[[National Motor Freight Traffic Association]]

revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=July 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Video games}} '''Nonviolent video games''' are [[video game]]s characterized by little or no [[Violence#Violence in the media|violence]]. As the term is vague, game designers, developers, and marketers that describe themselves as non-violent video game makers, as well as certain reviewers and members of the non-violent gaming community, often employ it to describe games with ''comparatively'' little or no violence. The definition has been applied flexibly to games in such purposive genres as the [[Christian video game]].<ref>''[http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/Beliefs/story?id=1042784&page=1 Christian Video Games Offer Wholesome Action: Game Makers Hope Non-Violent Alternatives Will Catch On]''. [[ABC News|ABC News/Technology]]. 17 August 2005.</ref> However, a number of games at the fringe of the "non-violence" label can only be viewed as objectively violent.
The purposes behind the development of the nonviolent genre are primarily reactionary in nature. As video quality and level of gaming technology have increased, the violent nature of some video games has gained worldwide attention from moral, political, gender, and medical/psychological quarters. The popularity of violent video games and increases in youth violence have led to much research into the degree to which video games may be blamed for societally negative behaviors. Despite the inconclusive nature of the scientific results, a number of groups have rejected violent video games as offensive and have promoted the development of non-violent alternatives. The existence of a market for such games has in turn led to the manufacture and distribution of a number of games specifically designed for the nonviolent gaming community. Video game reviewers have additionally identified a number of games belonging to traditionally violent gameplay genres as "nonviolent" in comparison to a typical game from the violent genre. Despite the fact that some of these games contain mild violence, many of them have entered the argot of nonviolent gamers as characteristic non-violent games.
==Video game violence and attendant controversies== {{Main article|Video game controversy#Crime and violence}}
Controversies surrounding the negative influences of video games are nearly as old as the medium itself. In 1964, [[Marshall McLuhan]], a noted media theorist, suggested in his book, ''[[Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man]]'', that "[t]he games people play reveal a great deal about them.<ref>McLuhan, Marshall. ''[[Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man]]''. Signet. 1964. Re-issued 1994. {{ISBN|0-262-63159-8}}.</ref> " This was built upon in the early 1980s in an anti-video-game crusade spearheaded by the former Long Island PTA president, Ronnie Lamm, who spoke about her cause on the [[PBS NewsHour|MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour]] in December 1982.<ref name=gonzalez>Gonzalez, Lauren. ''[http://www.gamespot.com/features/6090892 When Two Tribes Go to War: A History of Video Game Controversy]''. [[GameSpot]] feature. Retrieved 8 October 2008.</ref> The same year, [[Surgeon General of the United States|Surgeon General]], [[C. Everett Koop]], had suggested that games had no merit and offered little in the way of anything constructive to young people.<ref name=gonzalez/> Despite early general claims of the negative effects of video games, however, effects of these concerns were relatively minor prior to the early 1990s.
Discussion of the impact of violence in video games came as early as 1976's ''[[Death Race (1976 video game)|Death Race]]'' arcade game (a game with black and white graphics which involved running over screaming zombies). In the 1980s titles such as Exidy's ''[[Chiller (video game)|Chiller]]'' (1986), Namco's ''[[Splatterhouse]]'' (1987) and Midway's ''[[Narc (video game)|NARC]]'' (1988) raised concerns about video game violence in the arcade. Home games such as [[Palace Software|Palace]]'s ''[[Barbarian (Palace Software)|Barbarian]]'' (1987) featured the ability to decapitate opponents. It was not until graphic capabilities increased and a wave of new ultra-violent titles were released in the early 1990s that the mainstream news began to pay significant attention to the phenomenon. In 1992, with [[Midway Games|Midway]]'s release of the first ''[[Mortal Kombat (1992 video game)|Mortal Kombat]]'' video game, and then in 1993 with [[id Software|id]]'s ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'', genuine controversy was first ignited as the wide and growing popularity of violent video games came into direct conflict with the moral and religious ethics of concerned citizens. Protests and [[List of banned video games|game-bannings]] followed the publicizing of these conflicts, and controversies would erupt periodically throughout the 1990s with the releases of such games as ''[[Dreamweb]]'' (1992), ''[[Wolfenstein 3D]]'' (1992), ''[[Mortal Kombat II]]'' (1993), ''[[Phantasmagoria (video game)|Phantasmagoria]]'' (1995), ''[[Duke Nukem 3D]]'' (1996), ''[[Blood (video game)|Blood]]'' (1997), ''[[Grand Theft Auto (video game)|Grand Theft Auto]]'' (1997), ''[[Carmageddon]]'' (1997), ''[[Postal (video game)|Postal]]'' (1997), ''[[Mortal Kombat 3]]'' (1997), ''[[Carmageddon II: Carpocalypse Now]]'' (1998), ''[[Blood II: The Chosen]]'' (1998), ''[[Grand Theft Auto 2]]'' (1999), and ''[[Requiem: Avenging Angel]]'' (1999) among others.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Eric harris dylan klebold.jpg|thumb|right|[[Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold]], shown here on the [[Columbine High School]] security cameras during the [[Columbine High School massacre|massacre]], are alleged to have been directly inspired by such ultra-violent video games as ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'', ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'', and ''[[Duke Nukem 3D]]''.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/1295920.stm Columbine families sue computer game makers] ''bbc.co.uk''</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailycamera.com/shooting/2002/05lcolu.html |title= Columbine lawsuit over video games dismissed |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060428142549/http://www.thedailycamera.com/shooting/2002/05lcolu.html |archivedate=28 April 2006 }} – ''Associated Press (The Daily Camera)''</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.salon.com/technology/feature/1999/04/23/gamers/index.html| title = Doom, Quake and mass murder | accessdate = 24 August 2008| author = Janelle Brown| date= 23 April 1999| publisher = [[Salon.com]]| language = [[English language|English]]}}</ref> This is however without any scientific evidence and under dispute.]] --> In April 1999, the fears of the media and violence-watch groups were legitimated in their eyes as investigations into the lives of [[Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold]], the shooters in the [[Columbine High School massacre]], revealed that they had been fans of the video game, ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'', and had even created [[Doom WAD|levels]] for it today dubbed "the [[Harris levels]]". A great deal of discussion of violence in video games followed this event with strong arguments made on both sides, and research into the phenomenon which had begun during the 1980s received renewed support and interest.<ref>''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080422082626/http://mentalhealth.about.com/cs/familyresources/a/vidgameviolence.htm Violent Video Games Produce Violent Behavior]''. [[About.com]] article. 9 November 2005. Retrieved 8 October 2008.</ref>
In December 2001, [[Surgeon General of the United States|Surgeon General]] [[David Satcher]], led a study on violence in youth and determined that while the impact of video games on violent behavior has yet to be determined, "findings suggest that media violence has a relatively small impact on violence," and that "meta-analysis [had demonstrated that] the overall effect size for both randomized and correlational studies was small for physical aggression and moderate for aggressive thinking."<ref name=gonzalez/>
Despite this, the controversies and debate have persisted, and this has been the catalyst for the emergence of the non-violent video game genre. Non-violent video games are defined in the negative by a ''[[Modus tollendo ponens]]'' [[Disjunctive syllogism|disjunctive argument]]. In other words, in order to recognize a non-violent game, an identifier must recognize the violent game as a distinct class. This has led to a degree of ambiguity in the term as it relies upon a definition of [[violence]] which for different identifiers may mean different things. In general, violence may be placed into at least three distinct categories: *Totally non-violent games – Games in which absolutely no violence occurs. This category contains games characterized by lack of the death of characters, lack of sudden noise or movement, and often lack of traditional conflict. (e.g., ''[[Below the Root (video game)|Below the Root]]'' or ''[[Sudoku Gridmaster]]'') *Games in which the player acts non-violently – Games where violence occurs to the character-player as a result of environmental hazards or enemies but the character-player's reaction is to run away or otherwise distance himself from the violence. **Games with environmental hazards only – Games lacking enemies, but containing a potentially violent environment (E.g. ''[[Alleyway (video game)|Alleyway]]'', or ''[[Roller Coaster (video game)|Roller Coaster]]'') **Games with enemies – Games with violent enemies which the player-character must avoid (E.g. the ''[[Eggerland (series)|Eggerland]]'' series) *Games in which the player acts non-violently to other sentient beings – Games where a player acts violently against robots or other non-living non-sentient enemies (E.g. ''[[Descent (video game)|Descent]]'')
===Education=== The majority of these games have not been scientifically tested to see whether children learn the skills the games claim to teach.In another study performed in Chile, educational video games were put into some first and second grade classrooms. Children who had the games in their classroom showed more progress in math, reading comprehension, and spelling than the children who did not use games in their classrooms.<ref>http://www.cmch.tv/mentors_teachers/video_games_benefits.asp "Are there any benefits of playing video games" Accessed 13 April 2014</ref>
===Research=== {{Main article|Video game effects}}
The [[history of video games|history of video game development]] shares approximate contemporaneity with [[media violence research]] in general. In the early 1960, studies were conducted on the effects of [[adolescents and cartoon violence|violence in cartoons]],<ref>Mussen, P., & Rutherford, E. (1961). ''Effects of aggressive cartoons on children’s aggressive play''. Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology, 62, 461–464.</ref> and throughout the 1970s and 1980s a number of studies were conducted on how televised violence influenced viewers (especially younger viewers). The focus of many of these studies was on the effects of exposure of children to violence, and these studies frequently employed the [[social learning theory]] framework developed by [[Albert Bandura]] to explore violent behavioral modeling.
[[File:David Satcher official photo portrait.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Surgeon General of the United States|Surgeon General]] [[David Satcher]] has conducted research in the field of video game violence and has concluded that "findings suggest that media violence has a relatively small impact on [youth] violence."<ref name=gonzalez/>]] With advancements in video technology and the rise of video games containing graphic violence in the late 1980s and early 1990s, media violence research shifted to a great degree from televised violence to video game violence. Although under current debate, a number of researchers have claimed that violent games may cause more intense feelings of aggression than nonviolent games, and may trigger feelings of anger and hostility.<ref>Anderson, C. A., & Bushman, B. J. (2001). ''Effects of violent games on aggressive behavior, aggressive cognition, aggressive affect, physiological arousal, and prosocial behavior: A meta-analytical review of the scientific literature''. Psychological Science, 12, 353–359.</ref> Theoretical explanations for these types of effects have been explained in myriad theories including social cognitive theory, excitation transfer theory, priming effect and the [[Video game effects#General Aggression Model|General Aggression Model]]. However recent scholarship has suggested that social cognitive theories of aggression are outdated and should be retired.<ref>name=Ferguson & Dyck, 2012>{{cite journal|last=Ferguson|first=Christopher|title=Paradigm change in aggression research: The time has come to retire the General Aggression Model|journal=Aggression and Violence Behavior|year=2012|issue=17|pages=220–228|url=http://www.tamiu.edu/~cferguson/Paradigm%20Change.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927103208/http://www.tamiu.edu/~cferguson/Paradigm%20Change.pdf|archivedate=27 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
One difference between video games and television which nearly all media violence studies recognize is that video games are primarily interactive while television is primarily passive in nature.<ref>Kirsh, Stephen J. ''Children, Adolescents, and Media Violence – A Critical Look at the Research''. Media Violence and the Concept of Risk. [[SAGE Publications]]. 2006. p. 276. {{ISBN|0-7619-2976-2}}.</ref> Video game players identify with the character they control in the video games and there have been suggestions that the interactivity available in violent video games narrows the gap between the theory and practice of youth violence in a manner that goes beyond the effects of televised violence.<ref>Meyers, Kelly Stephen. ''[http://etd.lsu.edu/docs/available/etd-1107102-220029/unrestricted/Meyers_dis.pdf Television and Video Game Violence: Age Differences and the Combined Effects of Passive and Interactive Violent Media]''. Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College – Department of Psychology. December 2002.</ref><ref>Greenfield, Patricia Marks and Cocking, Rodney R. ''Interacting with video: Volume 11 of Advances in applied developmental psychology''. Greenwood Publishing Group. 1996. {{ISBN|1-56750-152-4}}</ref> Acknowledgment of the fact that, for better or worse, video games are likely to remain a part of modern society has led to a brace of comparative studies between violent games and non-violent games.<ref name=cooper>Cooper, J., & Mackie, D. (1986). ''Video games and aggression in children''. Journal of Applied Social Psychology, 16(8), 726–744.</ref><ref>Tamborini, R., Eastin, M. S., Skalski, P., Lachlan, K., Fediuk, T. A., & Brady, R. (2004). ''Violent virtual video games and hostile thoughts''. Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media, 48(3), 335–357.</ref><ref name=polman>Polman, H., de Castro, B. O., & van Aken, M. A. G. (2008). ''Experimental study of the differential effects of playing versus watching violent video games on children’s aggressive behavior''. Aggressive Behavior, 34(3), 256–264.</ref> As technology has advanced, such studies have adapted to include the effects of violent games and non-violent games in new media methods such as immersive virtual reality simulations.<ref>Arriaga, P., Esteves, F., Caneiro, P., & Monteiro, M. B. (2008). ''Are the effects of unreal violent video games pronounced when playing with a virtual reality system?'' Aggressive Behavior, 34(5), 521–538.</ref>
Results have varied, with some research indicating correlation between violence in video games and violence in players of the games, and other research indicating minimal if any relationship.<ref>Anderson, Craig & Dill, Karen. ''Video Games and Aggressive Thoughts, Feelings, and Behavior in the Laboratory and in Life''. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, April 2000 Vol. 78, No. 4, 772–790.</ref><ref>Silvern, S. B., & Williamson, P. A. (1987). The effects of video game play on young children’s aggression, fantasy, and prosocial behavior. Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, 8(4), 453–462.</ref> Despite the lack of solid conclusion on the issue, the suggestion that violent games cause youth violence together with the clear popularity of violent video game genres such as the [[first-person shooter]] have led some game designers to publish non-violent alternatives.<ref name=dobson>Dobson, Jason. ''[http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=9161 ACE, Christian Developers Conference Focuses On Responsible Game Development]''. [[Gamasutra]]. 3 May 2006.</ref><ref>''[http://www.gamezone.com/news/viewizard_announces_the_release_of_memonix_1_4 Viewizard announces the release of Memonix 1.4]''. GameZone. 28 April 2005.</ref>
===Lawsuits and legislation=== As research supporting the view that video game violence leads to youth violence has been produced, there have been a number of lawsuits initiated by victims to gain compensation for loss alleged to have been caused by video-game-related violence. Similarly, in the [[United States Congress|US Congress]] and the legislatures of states and other countries, a number of legislative actions have been taken to mandate rating systems and to curb the distribution of violent video games. At times, individual games considered too violent have been censored or banned in such countries as [[Censorship in Australia#Video games|Australia]], [[Law 3037/2002|Greece]], [[List of banned video games|etc.]]
[[File:JackThompsonAttorney.jpg|thumb|200px|Former attorney [[Jack Thompson (activist)|Jack Thompson]] has filed lawsuits against the makers of violent games, alleging the violent content causes real-world violence.]] In 1997, [[Christian right|Christian conservative]]<ref name=provenzo>Provenzo, Eugene F., Jr. and Jack Thompson. ''[http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/1019/p09s01-coop.html A political odd couple's advice on finding common ground]''. Christian Science Monitor. 19 October 2004.</ref> [[Activism|activist]] and (now former) attorney [[Jack Thompson (activist)|Jack Thompson]] brought suit against [[Atari]], [[Nintendo]], [[Sega]], and [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] on behalf of the victims of [[Heath High School shooting]] in ''[[Heath High School shooting|James v. Meow Media]]''. The suit was dismissed in 2000, absolving the companies of responsibility for the shooter's actions based on a lack of remedy under Kentucky [[tort]] law.<ref>''[http://www.freedomforum.org/templates/document.asp?documentID=16730 Federal appeals panel upholds dismissal of lawsuit against movie, video game makers]''. [[Associated Press]]. 2002.</ref> In 2002, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit|Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals]] upheld the dismissal, and in 2003, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] denied [[certiorari]], refusing to review the case because it was not dismissed on [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|1st Amendment]] grounds.<ref>''[http://www.freedomforum.org/templates/document.asp?documentID=17477 High court won't revive suit blaming Hollywood for school shooting]''. [[Associated Press]]. 2003.</ref>
In 2000, the County Council for St. Louis, Missouri enacted Ordinance 20,193 that barred minors from purchasing, renting, or playing violent video games deemed to contain any visual depiction or representation of realistic injury to a human or a "human-like being" that appealed to minors' "morbid interest in violence."<ref name=krug>Krug, Judith F. & Caldwell-Stone, Deborah. ''[http://www.mediainstitute.org/ONLINE/FAM2003/6-a.html Controversial Ruling Finds Video Games Not Protected Speech]''. 2002.</ref> This ordinance was challenged in 2001 by the Interactive Digital Software Association (IDSA) as violative of freedom of expression as guaranteed by the first amendment. The IDSA cited the 7th Circuit case of ''American Amusement Machine Association v. Kendrick''<ref>''American Amusement Machine Association v. Kendrick'', 244 F.3d 572 (7th Cir. 2001)</ref> as precedent suggesting that video game content was a form of freedom of expression, however in 2002 the Eastern District Court of Missouri ultimately issued the controversial ruling that "video games are not a form of expression protected by the First Amendment" in ''Interactive Digital Software Association v. St. Louis County''.<ref>''Interactive Digital Software Association v. St. Louis County'', 200 F. Supp. 2d 1126 (E.D. Mo. 2002).</ref>
In the aftermath of the [[Columbine High School massacre]], a $5 billion lawsuit was filed in 2001 against a number of video game companies and [[id Software]], the makers of the purportedly violent video game, ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'' by victims of the tragedy.<ref>''[http://www.freedomforum.org/templates/document.asp?documentID=13762 Federal suit blames video-game makers for Columbine shooting]''. [[Associated Press]]. 24 April 2001.</ref><ref>''[http://www.freedomforum.org/templates/document.asp?documentID=14784 'Doom' distributors seek dismissal of lawsuit]''. [[Associated Press]]. 3 September 2001.</ref> Also named in the suit were [[Acclaim Entertainment]], [[Activision]], [[Capcom]], [[Eidos Interactive]], [[Infogrames Entertainment, SA|GT Interactive Software]], [[Interplay Entertainment]], [[Nintendo]], [[Sony Computer Entertainment]], [[Square Co.]],<ref>''[http://www.freedomforum.org/templates/document.asp?documentID=14434 Violent video games are protected speech, companies say]''. [[Associated Press]]. 19 July 2001.</ref> [[Midway Games]], [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]], [[Atari Corporation]], Meow Media, and [[Sega]].<ref name=AP1>''[http://www.freedomforum.org/templates/document.asp?documentID=15820 Columbine lawsuit against makers of video games, movies thrown out]''. [[Associated Press]]. 5 March 2002.</ref> Violent video games mentioned by name included ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'', ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'', ''[[Redneck Rampage]]'', and ''[[Duke Nukem 3D|Duke Nukem]]''. The suit was dismissed by Judge Babcock in March 2002 in a ruling suggesting that a decision against the game makers would have a chilling effect on free speech. Babcock noted that "it is manifest that there is social utility in expressive and imaginative forms of entertainment, even if they contain violence."<ref name=AP1/>
In 2003, Washington State enacted a statute banning the sale or rental to minors of video games<ref>Morris, Chris. ''[http://money.cnn.com/2003/05/20/technology/gaminglaw Wash. bans 'violent' game sales]''. CNN/Money. 21 May 2003.</ref> containing "aggressive conflict in which the player kill, injures, or otherwise causes physical harm to a human form in the game who is depicted by dress or other recognizable symbols as a public law enforcement officer." In 2004, this statute was subsequently declared an unconstitutional violation of the first amendment right to free speech in the Federal District Court case of ''Video Software Dealers Ass'n v. Maleng''.<ref>Kramer, Irwin. ''Case-in-Point''. Legal Television Network. 2008.</ref>
In 2005, Jack Thompson brought suit against [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] and ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' in representation of the victims of the [[Devin Moore (murderer)|Devin Moore]] shooting incident. On 7 November 2005, Thompson withdrew from ''[[Strickland v. Sony]]'', stating, "It was my idea [to leave the case]." He was quick to mention that the case would probably do well with or without his presence. This decision followed scrutiny from Judge James Moore, however Thompson claimed he received no pressure to withdraw. At the same time, Judge James Moore had taken the motion to revoke Thompson's license under advisement. Jack Thompson appeared in court to defend his ''[[pro hac vice]]'' right to practice law in Alabama, following accusations that he violated legal ethics.<ref>DeWitt, Robert. ''[http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20051108/NEWS/511080361/1007 Attorney in Fayette case bows out]''. Tuscaloosa News. 8 November 2005.</ref> Shortly thereafter, the case was dismissed and Thompson's license was revoked following a denial of his ''pro hac vice'' standing<ref>Sinclair, Brendan. ''[http://www.gamespot.com/news/6140117.html Alabama judge tosses Thompson]''. [[GameSpot]]. 18 November 2005.</ref> by Judge Moore who noted that "Mr. Thompson's actions before this Court suggest that he is unable to conduct himself in a manner befitting practice in this state."<ref>Steel, Wade. ''[http://ps2.ign.com/articles/668/668345p1.html Jack Thompson's Alabama License Revoked]''. [[IGN]]. 21 November 2005</ref> In March 2006, the Alabama Supreme Court upheld Judge Moore's ruling against the dismissal of the case.<ref>Reeves, Jay. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927200539/http://www.al.com/newsflash/regional/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fnews-20%2F1143662355218050.xml&storylist=alabamanews Court rejects appeal in Alabama suit blaming game for slayings]''. Associated Press. 29 March 2006.</ref>
In 2005, California State Senator, [[Leland Yee]] introduced [[California Assembly Bills 1792 & 1793]] which barred ultra-violent video games and mandated the application of [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]] ratings for video games. Yee, a former [[Developmental psychology|child psychologist]] has [[Leland Yee#Video game controversies|publicly criticized]] such games as ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'' and ''[[Manhunt 2]]'', and opposes the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]]'s ''Global Gaming League''. Both of these bills were passed by the assembly and signed by Gov. [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] in October 2005. By December 2005, both bills had been struck down in court by Judge Ronald Whyte as unconstitutional, thereby preventing either from going into effect on 1 January 2006. Similar bills were subsequently filed in such states as Michigan and Illinois, but to date all have been ruled to be unconstitutional.<ref>Byrd, Patrick R. ''[http://www.houstonlawreview.org/archive/downloads/44-2_pdf/5_Byrd.pdf It’s All Fun And Games Until Someone Gets Hurt: The Effectiveness Of Proposed Video-Game Legislation On Reducing Violence In Children]''. Houston Law Review</ref>
In 2005, in reaction to such controversial games as ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'', Senator [[Hillary Clinton]] along with Senators [[Joe Lieberman]] and [[Evan Bayh]], introduced the [[Family Entertainment Protection Act]] (S.2126), intended to protect children from inappropriate content found in video games by imposing a federal mandate for inclusion of [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]] ratings.<ref>''[http://www.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/4682533.stm Clinton wades into GTA sex storm]''. BBC News. 14 July 2005. Retrieved 29 August 2006.</ref><ref>''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080731213523/http://clinton.senate.gov/news/statements/details.cfm?id=249368&& Senators Clinton, Lieberman Announce Federal Legislation to Protect Children from Inappropriate Video Games]''. Retrieved 18 December 2005.</ref> All three senators have actively sought restrictions on video game content with Sen. Lieberman denouncing the violence contained in video games and attempting to regulate sales of violent video games to minors, arguing that games should have to be labeled based upon age-appropriateness.<ref>Parents Action for Children. [https://web.archive.org/web/20061127020545/http://pac.nisgroup.com/learn/media/violent-video-game-legislation/ Parents’ Action Endorses New Clinton-Lieberman-Bayh Bill Banning the Sale of Violent Video Games to Minors.]. Retrieved 10 October 2006.</ref> Regarding ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'', Lieberman has stated, "The player is rewarded for attacking a woman, pushing her to the ground, kicking her repeatedly and then ultimately killing her, shooting her over and over again. I call on the entertainment companies—they've got a right to do that, but they have a responsibility not to do it if we want to raise the next generation of our sons to treat women with respect."<ref>''[https://web.archive.org/web/20040226001611/http://www.forbes.com/technology/sciences/newswire/2004/01/25/rtr1226141.html Lieberman denounces 'Grand Theft Auto' video game]''. ''[[Reuters]]''. ''[[Forbes]]''. 25 January 2004.</ref>
In June 2006, the Louisiana case of ''[[Entertainment Software Association v. Foti]]'' struck down a state statute that sought to bar minors from purchasing video games with violent content. The statute was declared an unconstitutional violation of the 1st Amendment. Amici filing briefs included [[Jack Thompson (activist)|Jack Thompson]].
On 27 September 2006, Senator [[Sam Brownback]] (R-KS) introduced the United States [[Truth in Video Game Rating Act]] (S.3935). The act would require the ESRB to have access to the full content of and hands-on time with the games it was to rate, rather than simply relying on the video demonstrations submitted by developers and publishers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate Proposes New ESRB Legislation|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=11030|work = [[Gamasutra]]|accessdate=9 October 2008}} 27 September 2006.</ref> Two days later, Congressman [[Fred Upton]] introduced the [[Video Game Decency Act]] (H.R.6120) to the House.
===Degrees of violence=== {{Main article|Video game content rating system}}
Video game rating boards exist in a number of countries, typically placing restrictions (suggested or under force of law) for content that is violent or sexual in nature. About 5% of games fall into a category rated "mature" and recommended to those 17 years old and older. Those games account for about a quarter of all video game sales.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2011-06-27-supreme-court-violent-video-games_n.htm | work=USA Today | first1=Joan | last1=Biskupic | first2=Mike | last2=Snider | title=Supreme Court rejects ban on violent video games | date=28 June 2011}}</ref> Gamers seeking violence find themselves increasingly age restricted as identified violence level increases. This means that non-violent games, which are the least restricted, are available to all players at any age. This moral or legislative public policy against violence has the indirect effect of encouraging players of all ages and especially younger players to play non-violent games, however it also produces something of a [[forbidden fruit]] effect. For this and other reasons, the effectiveness of rating systems such as the ESRB to actually curb violent gameplay in youth gaming has been characterized as futile.<ref>Dr. David Walsh (21 March 2000). ''[http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=ED441520&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=ED441520 The Impact of Interactive Violence on Children: Testimony submitted to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, United States Senate]''. (PDF). Retrieved 13 July 2008.</ref>
